title: Aerial video shows major fire ripping through homes in Manila
summary: Aerial video from the Philippines shows dozens of shanty homes burning in the Tondo area of Manila.

title: Boxing legend Ricky Hatton dies at 46 in Manchester home
summary: Fans grieve the loss of a fighter whose spirit transcended the confines of boxing.

title: Video: Qatari PM condemns Israeli attack ahead of emergency summit
summary: The Qatari PM was at an emergency international summit to discuss a joint response after the Israeli attack in Doha.

title: Simbu from Tanzania wins marathon gold in historic photo finish
summary: Alphonce Felix Simbu made history by becoming the first Tanzanian to win gold at a global athletic championship.

title: South Korea hosts US, Japan for joint air and naval exercise Freedom Edge
summary: North Korea has criticised the trilateral military drills as a 'reckless show of strength'.

title: New York Governor Hochul endorses Zohran Mamdani for mayor amid poll surge
summary: Kathy Hochul's nod comes after Trump described Mamdani's 22-point lead in polls as a 'rebellion against bad candidates'.

title: The Pitt wins best TV drama Emmy, as war on Gaza echoes at ceremony
summary: Hacks actress Hannah Einbinder, also an Emmy winner, calls for a free Palestine in her acceptance speech.

title: Live: 6-year-old twins among Palestinians killed in Israeli attacks on Gaza
summary: Israeli attacks on civilians and infrastructure continue across Gaza as Qatar hosts Muslim, Arab world leaders.

title: ‘More egalitarian’: How Nepal’s Gen Z used gaming app Discord to pick PM
summary: It was a first for an electoral democracy. Backers say it's more transparent than what politicians do. But it has risks.

title: Lula hails Bolsonaro verdict, tells Trump Brazil’s democracy not negotiable
summary: In NYT op-ed, Lula praises 'historic' sentencing of Bolsonaro on coup charges, slams US levies on Brazil as misguided.

title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk’s murder has ‘leftist ideology’, Utah governor says
summary: Governor Spencer Cox says the 22-year-old suspect spent time in 'dark places' online.

title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 1,299
summary: Here are the key events on day 1,299 of Russia’s war on Ukraine.

title: India vs Pakistan Asia Cup match hit by ‘no handshake’ controversy
summary: Indian captain Yadav and his squad did not indulge in the customary post-match handshakes with Pakistan.

title: Is there any prospect of ending Russia’s war in Ukraine?
summary: Can Trump fulfil his promise of ending the war, or is the conflict proving more complex than expected?

title: Israel kills 53 in Gaza, flattens more towers as toll from famine rises
summary: Israel intensifies its bombardment of Gaza City, levelling 16 buildings, including three towers, and killing dozens.

title: Un sommet à Doha pour répondre à Israël
summary: Afficher leur unité et faire front commun face à Israël : c'est l'objectif du sommet de dirigeants arabes et musulmans, lundi. En amont, le Premier ministre du Qatar, Mohammed ben Abdelrahmane Al-Thani, a exhorté dimanche la communauté internationale à "arrêter le deux poids deux mesures" avec Israël.

title: Flottille vers Gaza : "On fait ce qu'on peut à notre échelle", explique Adèle Haenel
summary: Adèle Haenel a rejoint la flottille (Global Sumud Flotilla) chargée d'aide humanitaire, partie à la fin août de Barcelone en direction de Gaza. "On fait ce qu'on peut à notre échelle. On a une charge énorme sur les épaules qui devrait revenir aux États", explique l'actrice en direct à Tunis. "On essaie de faire respecter le droit international."

title: Le Qatar exhorte la communauté internationale à arrêter le "deux poids deux mesures" avec Israël
summary: Le Premier ministre du Qatar, Mohammed ben Abdelrahmane al-Thani, a enjoint dimanche la communauté internationale à "cesser le deux poids deux mesures" et à sanctionner Israël après l'attaque menée mardi à Doha. Ces déclarations interviennent la veille d'un sommet réunissant les dirigeants de pays arabes et musulmans dans la capitale qatarie.

title: "Biens mal acquis": l'ex-Premier ministre libanais Najib Mikati visé par la justice française
summary: La justice française a ouvert une enquête visant Najib Mikati, ancien Premier ministre libanais et l’une des figures les plus influentes du pays du Cèdre. Avec son frère Taha, il est soupçonné d’avoir bâti un vaste patrimoine, en France et à l’étranger, grâce à des montages offshore et des acquisitions potentiellement frauduleuses.

title: Marco Rubio en Israël pour marquer le soutien de Washington, malgré l'attaque au Qatar
summary: Le chef de la diplomatie américaine, Marco Rubio, effectue dimanche une visite en Israël, quelques jours après une frappe israélienne qui visait des responsables du Hamas au Qatar, autre allié des États-Unis. Une visite qui "montre la force de l'alliance israélo-américaine", s'est félicité le Premier ministre Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Netanyahu affirme que "se débarrasser" des dirigeants du Hamas mettrait fin à la guerre à Gaza
summary: Le Premier ministre israélien, Benjamin Netanyahu, a affirmé samedi que l’élimination des dirigeants du Hamas mettrait un terme au conflit à Gaza, quelques jours après l'attaque menée par Israël contre des responsables du mouvement palestinien réunis à Doha.

title: Des militants israéliens posent la première pierre symbolique d’une colonie en Syrie
summary: Un groupe de colons israéliens extrémistes a traversé la frontière syrienne le 18 août, dans le Golan, pour poser symboliquement la pierre d’une nouvelle colonie. S’ils ont été rapidement rapatriés par l’armée israélienne, leur action a inquiété en Syrie.

title: Attaque de la flottille pour Gaza : une "agression préméditée" selon la Tunisie
summary: L'attaque qui a visé mardi un bateau de la flottille pour Gaza, amarré près de Tunis, était "une agression préméditée", a affirmé mercredi le ministère tunisien de l'Intérieur. Le ministère a indiqué dans un communiqué mener l'enquête pour "faire toute la lumière" sur l'affaire, afin que "l'opinion publique, pas seulement en Tunisie mais dans le monde entier, soit informée de l'identité de ceux ayant planifié (l'attaque), des complices et des exécutants de cette agression".

title: À Gaza, la musique comme échappatoire pour des jeunes Palestiniens
summary: Des jeunes Palestiniens se tournent vers la musique, cherchant un soulagement et une évasion de l'atmosphère de guerre et de destruction, malgré le manque d'instruments et les dures conditions de déplacement.

title: Le Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU condamne les frappes au Qatar
summary: L'attaque sans précédent menée mardi par Israël visait des responsables du mouvement islamiste palestinien Hamas réunis dans un complexe résidentiel en plein coeur de Doha, capitale du Qatar, pays médiateur dans les négociations en vue d'un cessez-le-feu dans la bande de Gaza.

title: L’échange de prisonniers entre Paris et Téhéran en phase finale
summary: Le ministre iranien des Affaires étrangères, Abbas Araghchi, a déclaré jeudi qu'un accord visant à échanger des prisonniers français en Iran contre une femme iranienne détenue en France approchait de sa "phase finale". "Je peux maintenant dire que nous sommes arrivés au point où (l'accord sur) l'échange des prisonniers français en Iran approche maintenant de sa phase finale", a déclaré M. Araghchi dans une interview télévisée, sans donner plus de détails.

title: Accord d'échange de prisonniers entre la France et l'Iran dans sa "phase finale"
summary: Le ministre iranien des Affaires étrangères, Abbas Araghchi, a déclaré jeudi qu'un accord visant à échanger des prisonniers français en Iran contre une femme iranienne détenue en France approchait de sa "phase finale".

title: L'Assemblée générale de l'ONU se prononce en faveur d'un État palestinien excluant le Hamas
summary: L'Assemblée générale de l'ONU a adopté vendredi à une large majorité la "déclaration de New York" visant à donner un nouveau souffle à la solution à deux États, israélien et palestinien, qui exclut pour la première fois le Hamas. Soutenue par la Ligue arabe et déjà co-signée par plusieurs pays, cette initiative vise à isoler le mouvement islamiste, préparer la reconnaissance d’un État palestinien et accroître la pression sur Israël pour mettre fin à la guerre à Gaza.

title: Le Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU condamne les frappes au Qatar, qui croit en son "rôle diplomatique"
summary: Dans une déclaration qui nécessite l'accord de ses 15 membres, donc aussi des États-Unis alliés d'Israël, le Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU a condamné jeudi les récentes frappes sur le Qatar sans toutefois nommer leur auteur Israël. Le Premier ministre du Qatar a salué cette déclaration de soutien et a assuré "croire pleinement en la médiation".

title: Un accord d'échange de prisonniers entre la France et l'Iran est imminent, selon Téhéran
summary: Le ministre iranien des Affaires étrangères, Abbas Araghchi, a annoncé jeudi que Paris et Téhéran approchent de la "phase finale" d'un accord prévoyant un échange de prisonniers français en Iran contre l'Iranienne Mahdieh Esfandiari, détenue en France pour promotion du terrorisme.

title: Bloody Sunday : un ancien soldat britannique jugé à Belfast plus de 50 ans après les faits
summary: Surnommé « soldat F », l’ancien parachutiste est accusé de deux meurtres commis le 30 janvier 1972 à Londonderry et de cinq tentatives de meurtre. En décembre, il avait plaidé non coupable.

title: En Hongrie, la communauté juive se déchire sur la guerre à Gaza
summary: Une pétition signée par 1 500 juifs hongrois dénonçant « la destruction totale » de l’enclave palestinienne a lancé un débat dans la plus grande communauté d’Europe centrale.

title: Succession d’Armani : bataille en vue parmi les géants du luxe LVMH, L’Oréal et EssilorLuxottica
summary: Dans son testament, Giorgio Armani, mort le 4 septembre, demande aux héritiers de faire entrer au capital de la maison de couture italienne une multinationale du secteur puis de lui en confier le contrôle.

title: Au Mexique, coup de filet spectaculaire contre un réseau de contrebande d’hydrocarbures géré par des militaires
summary: En s’attaquant à des fonctionnaires du gouvernement de son prédécesseur et mentor, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, la présidente mexicaine, Claudia Sheinbaum, rompt avec la tradition consistant à étouffer les scandales survenus sous un gouvernement issu du même parti.

title: En direct, guerre en Ukraine : la Roumanie convoque l’ambassadeur russe à Bucarest, après l’intrusion d’un drone dans son espace aérien
summary: La Roumanie est le deuxième pays de l’OTAN qui voit son espace aérien violé par un drone russe après la Pologne. La ministre des affaires étrangères roumaine, Oana Toiu, a annoncé que l’ambassadeur russe à Bucarest avait été convoqué pour « communiquer clairement la protestation de la Roumanie ».

title: En direct, Gaza : les bombardements israéliens dans la ville de Gaza ont fait 16 morts, dont trois enfants, depuis l’aube, selon l’agence WAFa
summary: Une personne a, par ailleurs, été tuée par balle dans le centre de la bande de Gaza, affirme l’agence de presse palestinienne, lundi matin.

title: « Le fait que le rapport Draghi reste en jachère à 90 % doit nous inquiéter : ces atermoiements finiront par se payer cash »
summary: Si l’UE ne parvient pas à augmenter ses capacités d’investissement, il lui sera impossible de rester souveraine, explique dans sa chronique Stéphane Lauer, éditorialiste au « Monde ».

title: Florence Gaub et Roderick Parkes, chercheurs : « La question n’est pas de savoir si l’Occident est trop mou pour se battre, mais sous quelles conditions il le ferait »
summary: Dans une tribune au « Monde », deux chercheurs du collège de défense de l’OTAN interrogent la supposée aversion des populations occidentales pour l’engagement militaire. Il s’agit, à leurs yeux, d’un profond malentendu, qui participe à nourrir les discours qui associent la démocratie à la fragilité.

title: Airbus, Thales et Leonardo prêts à fusionner leurs activités satellites pour lutter contre Starlink
summary: Les trois industriels européens pourraient signer un accord de rapprochement d’ici à la fin de l’année.

title: Elections en Russie : le parti de Vladimir Poutine n’a plus besoin de faire campagne pour gagner
summary: Des élections locales se sont tenues à travers la Russie, du 12 et du 14 septembre. A Kostroma, ville touristique de 250 000 habitants au nord-est de Moscou, la campagne a été des plus mornes, symptôme d’une société étouffée par la répression et gagnée par l’apathie et la lassitude.

title: « Depuis le retour de Trump, une simple déclaration suffit pour que l’on parle d’accord commercial »
summary: Dans une tribune au « Monde », le professeur de droit Julien Chaisse alerte sur la fragilisation du commerce mondial et des pratiques démocratiques, à l’heure où l’Union européenne s’inspire des méthodes états-uniennes pour afficher un accord transatlantique dénué de base juridique solide.

title: Changement climatique : l’Australie confrontée à une multitude de risques pour son avenir, avertit un rapport
summary: Une étude destinée au gouvernement établit une série de risques sanitaires, économiques et environnementaux inédits alors que le pays doit dévoiler, dans la semaine, ses prochains objectifs de réduction de ses émissions de gaz à effet de serre.

title: Les femmes de la famille Clain, l’histoire d’un djihadisme ordinaire
summary: Christine Allain, 67 ans, Jennyfer Clain, 34 ans, nièce des frères Clain – les propagandistes de l’organisation Etat islamique (EI) qui avaient revendiqué les attentats du 13-Novembre –, et Mayalen Duhart, 42 ans, sont toutes accusées d’avoir rejoint l’EI en Syrie entre 2014 et 2017.

title: Vives réactions en Allemagne après l’annulation d’un concert d’un chef d’orchestre israélien en Belgique
summary: Lahav Shani, futur chef de l’Orchestre philharmonique de Munich, s’est vu reprocher par les organisateurs du festival de Gand de n’avoir pas « suffisamment clarifié » son attitude à l’égard du « régime génocidaire » israélien.

title: Les sanctions contre la Russie, pomme de discorde entre les Etats-Unis et l’Europe face à la Chine
summary: Avant d’accentuer la pression sur Vladimir Poutine, Donald Trump exige de ses alliés européens qu’ils cessent d’acheter du pétrole russe et augmentent les droits de douane sur les produits chinois. Inacceptable pour l’UE, qui doit présenter, lundi, un 19ᵉ train de mesures et craint de faire les frais d’une guerre commerciale entre Washington et Pékin.

title: Israeli forces kill worker attempted to cross separation wall near Jerusalem
summary:
Israeli forces kill worker attempted to cross separation wall near Jerusalem

Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian worker who attempted to cross the separation wall in the town of al-Ram, north of occupied east Jerusalem.

The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) said that it recovered his body from the Dahiya area of ​​Jerusalem.

The Israeli military confirmed the killing.

title: From Israeli prisons to UK courts, health workers will not be silenced
summary:
From Israeli prisons to UK courts, health workers will not be silenced

Submitted by Dr Omar Abdel-Mannan on Fri, 09/12/2025 - 15:22
In Gaza, doctors are imprisoned for treating children; in Britain, they are arrested for demanding an end to the arms sales that kill those children
A protester is carried away by police officers at a demonstration in support of Palestine Action in central London on 6 September 2025 (Justin Tallis/AFP)
Off

Nearly nine months after his abduction by Israeli forces, Dr Hussam Abu Safiya - a highly respected paediatrician from Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza - is wasting away in an Israeli prison cell. 

His lawyer, Gheed Kassem, describes a man who has lost a third of his body weight, whose skin is covered in boils and untreated infections, and who is denied even the most basic access to sunlight, showers and medicine. Allowed only 30 minutes of sun a month, he is starved, tortured and deprived of legal defence.

Abu Safiya’s most recent words, smuggled out through his lawyer, are haunting: “I entered in the name of humanity, and I will leave in the name of humanity. I am the one who was abducted from inside the hospital. We will remain on our land and continue to provide healthcare services to the people, God willing, even from a tent.”

This is the voice not of a criminal, but of a doctor - abducted in his white coat outside a destroyed hospital, ordered to walk towards an Israeli tank, in full view of the world. It was a deliberate spectacle. The message was clear: in Gaza, even medicine is a crime.

Abu Safiya is not alone. Since Israel’s assault began in October 2023, around 1,600 health workers have been killed, and hundreds more have been illegally detained, many of whom have disappeared. 

The deliberate targeting of Gaza’s doctors, nurses and paramedics is not collateral damage; it is policy. To dismantle a healthcare system, you must first destroy those who hold it up.

But the war on health workers does not stop at Gaza’s borders. In Britain, a parallel assault is underway - subtler, less bloody, but cut from the same cloth. 

In recent weeks, more than two dozen health workers - both practising and retired - have been arrested by UK police. Their supposed crime? Holding up cardboard signs in support of Palestine Action, a direct action group recently proscribed under terrorism legislation. Among those detained was the former editor-in-chief of the British Medical Journal.

Speaking out against war crimes

These individuals are not criminals or terrorists. They are compassionate professionals who have devoted their lives to caring for others, and who stand firmly within a proud tradition: health workers speaking out against war crimes and systemic injustice. 

Their arrests mark an unprecedented criminalisation of conscience. Arresting health workers for opposing the ban on Palestine Action is to erase the line between dissent and terrorism.

Health workers, bound by oath and by conscience, must never be silenced in the face of genocide and systemic violence

This is not just about Palestine. It is about the systematic degradation of civil liberties in Britain. A government that brands health workers as extremists for holding cardboard signs is a government that has abandoned the most basic democratic protections. 

Today it is Palestine; tomorrow it could be climate protest, trade union action, or academic speech. The message is simple: solidarity itself is suspect.

And all this while the UK government continues its active complicity in Israel’s onslaught. British weapons, parts and diplomatic cover enable the destruction of Gaza’s hospitals and the killing of its health workers. Ministers lecture health workers at home, while helping to silence and starve them abroad. That contradiction shatters any claim to moral credibility.

On 8 September, health workers across the UK answered back. Thousands gathered in vigils and protests outside Royal Colleges in London and other cities, and signed petitions calling for urgent action. Silence is complicity, they noted - and by refusing to speak, our institutions are colluding in war crimes.

Our duty to humanity 

Royal Colleges and medical institutions must now decide where they stand. Will they continue to sit on their hands, offering platitudes while their members are arrested in Britain and their colleagues are tortured in Gaza? Or will they act - lobbying government, defending freedom of speech, and demanding the protection of health workers everywhere? Anything less is a betrayal.

The duty of health workers has never been confined to the clinic. From anti-apartheid campaigns in South Africa, to protests against the Iraq War, our profession has always had a responsibility to confront injustice. To heal wounds without naming the forces that cause them is to abandon our vocation. 

Dr Abu Safiya symbolised humanity in Gaza. Israel and the West are destroying it
Read More »

The parallel between Abu Safiya’s cell and the police vans of London could not be clearer. In Gaza, doctors are imprisoned for treating children. In Britain, doctors are arrested for demanding an end to the arms sales that kill those children. Both are punished for insisting that medicine cannot be separated from justice.

And yet, despite everything, the voices of health workers have not been silenced. From Abu Safiya’s prison cell to the cardboard signs outside British courts, from vigils at Royal Colleges to petitions signed by thousands, a common message is clear: medicine is humanity, and humanity cannot be criminalised.

The question is whether the rest of our profession will stand with them. Will we allow our colleagues to be dragged through prisons and police vans without protest? Will we allow the government to arm Israel abroad, while criminalising dissent at home? Or will we insist, as Abu Safiya insists, that our duty as health workers is to humanity itself - to preserve life, alleviate suffering and speak truth, even when the cost is high?

Health workers, bound by oath and by conscience, must never be silenced in the face of genocide and systemic violence. Upholding this duty is not only essential to the integrity of our profession; it is essential to humanity itself.

The views expressed in this article belong to the author and do not necessarily reflect the editorial policy of Middle East Eye.

Israel's genocide in Gaza
Opinion

title: Gaza death toll rises
summary:
Gaza death toll rises

Israeli attacks have killed at least 28 Palestinians in Gaza since dawn today, including 20 in Gaza City, Al Jazeera Arabic reported, citing sources in Gaza hospitals.

Three people were shot dead in the Al-Mawasi area, southwest of Khan Younis.

In a separate report, the Quds Media Network stated that seven children died this morning at Nasser Medical Complex in Khan Younis, including four fetuses lost in utero and three premature babies who died in incubators.

Seven children died this morning at Nasser Medical Complex in Khan Younis, including four fetuses lost in utero and three premature babies who died in incubators.

Their deaths resulted from their mothers' severe malnutrition, extreme fear, constant stress, and exhaustion caused… pic.twitter.com/FjOANNu7JY

— Quds News Network (@QudsNen) September 15, 2025

title: Israeli forces stop school buses, detain students near Jerusalem
summary:
Israeli forces stop school buses, detain students near Jerusalem

Israeli forces blocked the movement of school students in Shu'fat refugee camp, north of occupied East Jerusalem, on Monday morning, the Wafa news agency reported. 

Local sources said the military stopped several buses carrying students from leaving the camp and detained dozens of children in the waiting area near the checkpoint at the entrance.

title: Israeli attacks kill at least eight Palestinians in Gaza
summary:
Israeli attacks kill at least eight Palestinians in Gaza

An Israeli attack on a tent sheltering displaced families killed seven people, including three children, in the west of Gaza City, Al Jazeera reported.

Another person has been killed by Israeli gunfire in central Gaza’s al-Mughraqa, the network said, citing a medical source at al-Awda Hospital.

title: Emmys red carpet becomes stage for Gaza solidarity
summary:
Emmys red carpet becomes stage for Gaza solidarity

Israel's genocidal war in Gaza was on the minds of some Emmys attendees as television's biggest stars gathered in Los Angeles on Sunday for the 77th Primetime Emmy Awards, the industry's premier awards gala on Sunday.

Megan Stalter, one of the breakout stars of comedy powerhouse "Hacks," showed up casual in a white t-shirt and jeans, but her handbag did all the talking.

The black purse had white tape on it with a simple message: “Ceasefire!”

And Javier Bardem, a nominee for best supporting actor in a limited series for "Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story," wore a black and white keffiyeh around his neck in support of Palestinians.

"A lot of people are giving me their support in whispers, and I go, 'Don't whisper, say it out loud'," Bardem told AFP on the red carpet.

“We target film companies and film institutions that are complicit and are related to whitewashing or justifying the genocide in Gaza and for Israel, of Israel, and its apartheid regime,” he said.

title: Morning update
summary:
Morning update

Good morning Middle East Eye readers,

here are the latest updates:

  • Days after Israel's attack in Qatar, Donald Trump warned Israel on Sunday that "Qatar is a very good ally." He said, "Israel and everyone else, you have to be careful. When you attack people, you have to be careful."

  • The Israeli army attacked a building holding the largest archaeological collection in the Gaza Strip on Sunday, according to the French Biblical and Archaeological Research Institute, Ecole Biblique.

  • The Israeli army detonated 6 booby-trapped robots in the southern areas of Gaza City, according to the Palestinian Information Centre.

  • The Israeli military arrested a young man from the Syrian village of al-Rafid, near the border with Israel, during a raid, Saudi news channel Al-Hadath reported.

title: Evening recap
summary:
Evening recap

Our live blog will shortly be closing until tomorrow morning.

Here are the day's key developments:

  • At least 53 people have been killed since dawn by Israeli forces.

  • Gaza's Ministry of Health reported two more deaths from malnutrition in the past 24 hours, bringing the official famine toll to 422, including 145 children.

  • Israeli forces have flattened a residential tower in Gaza City's al-Rimal neighbourhood, less than two hours after issuing expulsion orders to residents.

  • Doctors Without Borders (MSF) warned that the forced expulsion of Gaza City residents - including hundreds of gravely ill patients and newborns - into overcrowded, under-resourced areas would amount to “a death sentence for one million Palestinians.”

  • Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said on Sunday that Israel's "practices" will not stop Doha's mediation efforts with Egypt and the US to end the war in Gaza.

  • Israeli conductor Ilan Volkov denounced Israel's genocide in Gaza in a speech following a performance at London's BBC proms at the Royal Albert Hall on Saturday.

  • US Secretary of State Marco Rubio arrived in Israel for a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the aftermath of the Israeli attack on Doha.

  • President Isaac Herzog has cautioned that Israel must not “forsake” its relationships with Arab states, even as leaders gather in Doha in response to Israel’s recent strike in Qatar.

  • The Israeli says 20,000 soldiers and officers have been wounded since 7 October 2023.

title: Turkish FM blasts Israel ahead of Arab-Islamic summit
summary:
Turkish FM blasts Israel ahead of Arab-Islamic summit

Turkey’s Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan told Al Jazeera in Doha that Israel’s war on Gaza amounts to genocide and warned Arab and Islamic states must unite against its expansionist drive.

“There is an occupation of Palestine and an ongoing genocide in Gaza. Israel is acting with an expansionist mindset,” he said.

Fidan accused Israel of seeking a “Greater Israel” by destabilising countries such as Syria, and criticised Washington for putting its relationship with Israel above all else, calling it damaging to US credibility in the region.

He added that President Erdoğan continues to condemn Israel’s “crimes, killing of civilians and expansionist policies,” warning they threaten global security and the international order.

title: Pro-Palestine protest halts Spain cycling finale in Madrid
summary:
Pro-Palestine protest halts Spain cycling finale in Madrid

Pro-Palestine demonstrators disrupted the final stage of Spain’s premier cycling race in Madrid, forcing an early halt after clashes erupted with riot police.

The protest targeted the Israel-Premier Tech team over Israel’s war on Gaza. Tensions escalated when crowds toppled barriers and poured onto the route during the closing stretch of the tour.

Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez earlier praised those protesting, saying he felt “admiration for the Spanish people mobilising for just causes like Palestine.”

Madrid’s Mayor Jose Luis Martinez-Almeida accused Sanchez of “instigating the protests.”

title: Growing numbers of universities sever ties with Israeli academia over Gaza genocide
summary:
Growing numbers of universities sever ties with Israeli academia over Gaza genocide

Mounting numbers of universities and academic bodies across Europe and South America are severing ties with Israeli institutions over concerns of their complicity with Israel's genocide in Gaza.

Last year, Brazil's Federal University of Ceara (UFC) cancelled an innovation summit with an Israeli university, while universities across Norway, Belgium and Spain cut links with Israeli institutions.

This year, others, including Trinity College in Dublin, have followed suit.

In March, the University of Amsterdam announced it was halting a student exchange programme with the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, while the European Association of Social Anthropologists declared it would not collaborate with Israeli academic institutions.

However, most universities in the UK, France and Germany have resisted mounting pressure from staff and students to do the same.

Read more: Growing numbers of universities sever ties with Israeli academia over Gaza genocide

title: Faith, politics, and armed resistance: A Palestinian-Christian perspective
summary:
Faith, politics, and armed resistance: A Palestinian-Christian perspective

When Hatem El-Sayegh addressed a crowd of more than 550 at the Palestinian-Christian-led Church at the Crossroads conference, he said that his remarks were not intended for people to walk away feeling "pro-Palestine," but rather "pro-Christ," because ultimately, the moral path is the godly one, he said.

"We, especially in an individualistic society, measure everything from our own position," he later told Middle East Eye. "It's me, me, me. Christ is for me [and] if I was the only one in the world, Christ would have come for me... but the exclusive Christ is inclusive for all who come to him". 

Like most of Gaza's Muslims, its small Christian community is also religiously devoted and has clung to their faith to get them through two years of what is, by legal definition, a genocide carried out by Israel. 

"Right now it's revolutionary to be pro-Palestinian, but I think what is consistently that revolutionary is to be ever loving in Christ," Hatem's daughter Lydia, who works with the Quaker-inspired Friends Committee on National Legislation, told MEE. 

Read more: Faith, politics, and armed resistance: A Palestinian-Christian perspective

title: Israeli president warns against 'burning bridges' with Arab partners
summary:
Israeli president warns against 'burning bridges' with Arab partners

President Isaac Herzog has cautioned that Israel must not “forsake” its relationships with Arab states, even as leaders gather in Doha in response to Israel’s recent strike in Qatar.

Speaking at a memorial for late Israeli leaders, Herzog stressed that Israel maintains “extensive and significant ties” with several Arab countries, including economic links, according to The Times of Israel.

“They are part of the Western-facing world in which we seek to remain, and in these countries there is also a large and important public supportive of Israel, who yearn to hear our voice,” he said.

Herzog urged continued engagement, saying Israel should act “with purpose and determination” through diplomacy and outreach. “We must not forsake our ties. We must not burn our bridges,” he added.

title: First Gaza children head to UK for medical care, officials say
summary:
First Gaza children head to UK for medical care, officials say

The United Kingdom’s health ministry says the first group of sick and injured children from Gaza are en route to Britain for urgent medical care.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer first outlined the plan in July, pledging to bring Palestinian children to the UK as hospitals inside Gaza struggle to function.

Officials say the programme has become critical, with shortages of medicines and supplies in the enclave and doctors unable to work safely.

A health ministry statement said the children will travel with close family members and are expected to arrive “in the coming weeks”. No flight details have been released, with the ministry citing “operational security reasons”.

Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper told the Daily Mirror on Friday that the first group “have left Gaza and are on the way... to the UK”.

The newspaper reported that the children are currently receiving care in another country in the region before continuing on to Britain.

title: Drone strike targets car in southern Lebanon, injuries reported
summary:
Drone strike targets car in southern Lebanon, injuries reported

Lebanon’s National News Agency says a drone strike hit a vehicle travelling between Toulin and Burj Qalaouiyah in the country’s south, leaving several people injured.

Local outlet An-Nahar reported that an “Israeli drone” carried out the attack and published footage, showing a car engulfed in flames as an ambulance arrived at the scene.
